title: Cardano news in Chinese
description: 台湾では、多くの人がADAを知っていますが、Cardano Project Catalystを知っている人はごくわずかです。これは、言葉の壁によるものです。

f6_assessments.q0: This could be a good project to bring Chinese speaking Taiwanese into the Cardano family. However at over 40% of the challenge budget, it needs to show clear benefits to voters to be successfully funded over other projects. How many people does it expect to bring in and in what capacity?
f6_assessments.q1: The team claims to have the experience necessary to deliver the project, however some examples or references to back this up would be good. Without this is is hard to know if they have the capability to successfully deliver. The plan is sparse in details. A key comp0oenent is the online and offline seminars. What content will these be covering and who is the target audience. Is it technical or just introductory to Cardano? Will these seminars be run for profit, will tickets be sold?
f6_assessments.q2: Whilst provision of the deliverables under this proposal is relatively straight forward, it lacks information about measuring success. This challenge is about motivating non0english speakers to learn and grow Cardano. How many new members do you aim to reach? What audience sizes for the conferences? how will you measure how they help grow the community? How much of what you are doing will focus on Taiwan rather than the larger Chinese audience in China and worldwide?

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal to let people in Taiwan know ADA and Cardano Project Catalyst by holding seminars and create Youtube tutorial videos in Chinese to make the project more visible to entrepreneurs in Taiwan.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers includes numerous bilingual members who can provide translation, interpretation, and localization strategies which makes the proposal highly likely to be implemented
f6_assessments.q2: Extremely well thought out plans and KPIs - the budget may need to be increased to include the ability to attract more user adoption.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal identified the language barrier problem in Taiwan in relation to Catalyst knowledge. As a solution, the idea of creating youtube tutorials and seminars in Chinese was presented and metrics for evaluating the project's performance were presented. The purpose of the proposal is in line with the challenge. The project did not have any revenue planning beyond Catalyst so it is not possible to assess whether it will be financially sustainable in the future.
f6_assessments.q1: The team appears to have relevant experience for implementing the work but no evidence of their abilities was presented. The proposer said that a team of members will carry out the project but he did not specify who the members are and their respective experiences. The budget was well detailed but it seems a little overpriced. The deadline seems reasonable. The proposal does not pose any risk that would prevent its implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer presented a roadmap and KPIs. It would be interesting to cite milestones as well. The proposal lacks metrics to assess the project's success, such as the number of video views and seminar participants.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal effectively addresses the challenge of increasing Cardano exposure in China. The goal is to hold seminars and create Youtube tutorials in Chinese to make the project more visible to entrepreneurs in Taiwan.
f6_assessments.q1: This team seems capable of a successful proposal, and the plan is to provide a large social media campaign to native Chinese speakers.
f6_assessments.q2: The key performance indicators (KPIs) are well thought-out, and the timeline is reasonable. The ability to audit this proposal needs clearer metrics that can be easily viewed to determine if the proposal is successful.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is clearly about multilingual resources, and Chinese is a crucial language for these resources. However, it involves a variety of related initiatives rather than a clear, unified proposal. There is also a mismatch between the stated project scope and specific deliverables. For example, item #1 on scope is a social media account, but the detailed plan does not relate to this. Conversely, much of the budget is for translation of Fund 6 winning proposals, but this is not part of the stated scope. 

I would advise the proposers to focus on building out more clearly one or a few elements of this proposal. With respect to translation, for example, what could be a sustainable approach for ongoing translation of Cardano materials (rather than just Fund 6 winning proposals)? Could there be efficiencies using Google Translate (or Google Translate plus quality control) or similar rather than paying for translations? How will the proposal deal with presenting translations in traditional Chinese (used in Taiwan) vs. simplified Chinese (used in mainland China)?

Similarly, for the proposed offline and online events, what would they be about? Who would be the speakers? How would they be tied into the broader Cardano / Catalyst community?
f6_assessments.q1:
Because the proposal presents a variety of related initiatives in a somewhat unclear structure (see comments on impact criterion), it is difficult to understand what would be accomplished. Therefore, it is hard to be confident that the proposal would be implemented successfully. There is also limited information about team skills, including no information about skills to organize the proposed events.

In addition, some elements of the budget could probably be managed more efficiently. For example, why is it necessary to pay $2000 for speakers, and who would the speakers be who need such payment? Often it is possible to get speakers to speak for free particularly for community events.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal includes specific KPIs, which are measurable. However, as noted in my other comments, these KPIs do not match to the project scope (which is somewhat unclear). Thus, it would be challenging to audit for the actual scope. Therefore, I neither agree nor disagree that the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The "headlines" of this proposal are about creating tutorial videos in Chinese, and building community through seminars, meet-ups and social media engagement in Chinese. This addresses the challenge well (although it would have helped with assessing impact if the proposal had included details of which social media accounts will be used to share info – are they already established accounts with plenty of followers, or new ones? – and a bit more detail on what topics the video tutorials will cover.

But then, the project's KPIs introduce an additional piece of work that's not mentioned in the "project scope", and which therefore seems to come a little bit out of left field - the idea of providing translations to the funded projects in Fund 6. The impact here is a little less clear, since it's not clear what material would be translated – I guess progress reports from the projects, so that Chinese speakers can engage with their activities? If so, that would probably have some positive impact, but I feel unsure how much; and it is a little confusing that this is the main part of the work, but it's not mentioned in the initial project description, which sounds as if videos and meetups are the core of the work. The project still sounds like it would have a positive impact overall, but impact would be clearer if the main part of the work was in the headline.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal team have translation skills, but they don't mention any video production skills, experience of creating educational materials, community engagement skills or social media and marketing skills. Many of these things are in the budget, so they are probably being bought in from outside; but if so, it would be good to know something about who will be doing the work and what experience they have. It would also be great to know of any management experience the proposal team has, as they will presumably be managing other staff.
The budget  is clear and well broken down – but one or two of the items are a little surprising as they weren't mentioned in the earlier description of the project (e.g. the translations, as noted above, and the guest speaker fees, a surprise because the seminars sounded more like a place to chat and discuss Cardano between equals, rather then listen to prominent speakers). The effect of this is that the project comes across as a bit muddled – it would be better if the project plan/description matched up more closely with what's in the budget. Taken together, all this leaves me a little unsure about the feasibility of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: There is plenty of auditable information here: engagements on social media, video views and comments, amount of material translated, and attendees at meetups. So yes, the progress and success are auditable. The only thing that's missing is an assessment of whether the participants and video-viewers do feel that the project has made it "easier for non-English speakers to build and grow the Cardano community in their local areas", as the challenge setting puts it. This is not easy to assess, but it would be great if the project could add it in somehow – perhaps by a survey or online poll at the end of the project?

f6_assessments.q0: They explained their budget, they have timeline and a half plan. This is a great proposal! It does request a large amount of money and the plan could definitely have some more detail about how they are going to get people to know about these videos, how long will it take to create them and how many they are planning to create. Another thing I would add is that the project scope is going to be completed in12 months whilst the brief states that thy want to attract people in 3-6 months.
f6_assessments.q1: Their idea is amazing and has been proposed really well. They have a timeline and an explained budget, as well as lots of bilingual team members. It is hard to implement something when you don't have a full plan though.
f6_assessments.q2: There is a timeline as well as a reasoned budget and lots of experience, this makes this easy to audit the success and progress towards their goal of Youtube tutorials in Chinese for people in Taiwan. The short unexplained plan is a bit of a letdown.

solution: 台湾の起業家にプロジェクトを知ってもらうために、セミナーを開催したり、中国語でYoutubeのチュートリアルビデオを作成したりする。
experience: 私たちのチームには、翻訳、通訳、ローカリゼーション戦略を提供できる多数のバイリンガルメンバーがいます。
